column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

There were  1085 exports and 435 trade cattle. Amongst the exports were 495 cows, with very few dairy cows offered this week. A few new faces were at the rails and competition was strong on the finished heavy steers and bullocks. The trade section consisted of a lot of lighter weighted yearlings and vealer calves and showed mixed pricing trends. Feedlot and store buyer activity was alive and well, with a range of weight categories on offer. 

The vealers ranged from 270c to a top of 350c/kg, with a large percentage under 300kg live weight. Only the odd yearling steer went to the trade and made to 370c/kg, as most yearling steers suited store buyers and made from 285c to 326c/kg. The yearling heifer portion to processors reached 365c/kg. The store heifers made from 270c to 319c/kg and were once again mainly light weights.

The 400 to 500kg steers ranged from 300c to 330c/kg, the 500 to 600kg steers C3 and C4 made from 312c to 370c/kg to average 351c/kg, while the 600kg plus bullocks made from 319c to 350c/kg to average 336c/kg which was 10c to 15c/kg better on last week for the top end C4 steers.

The heavy beef cows made from 245c to 290c/kg to average 286c/kg for the D4â€™s and the dairy cows made from 218c to 270c/kg.
